conversation.content: [shocked] Dad? Is thatâ€”is that actually you under that venue maintenance uniform, or am I just, um, seeing things because I haven't slept in two days preparing for tonight's show?

[very quietly] Hello, Marie. [clearing throat] Yeah, it's me. I, uh, I didn't know you were performing here tonight, they just said there was a heating issue in the main theater that needed immediate attention.

[bitter] Twenty years, Dad. Twenty goddamn years of nothing, and you just happen to show up here fixing the heat on the biggest night of my tribute career? [laughs] That's either cosmic irony or you knew exactly what you were doing.

I've been working this venue for three months now, had no idea you were, well, doing this Elvis thing professionally. [pause] Your mother never mentioned it in her letters before she stopped writing them.

[shaky voice] She stopped writing because she died, Dad. [exhales] Two years ago, cancer, and I had to explain to everyone at the funeral why her husband wasn't there, why he hadn't been there for two decades.

[regretful] I know about the cancer, Marie. I, uh, I tried to come back when I heard she was sick, but she told me to stay away, said you'd built a life without me and it would just make things harder. [sighs]

[crying while speaking] You believed her? You just took that as permission to stay gone? God, I spent years defending you to her, telling her you must have had your reasons, that maybe you'd come back when you were ready.
[very quietly] I wasn't ready. Still not.

[frustrated] You know what's funny? I sing 'Can't Help Falling in Love' every night, and all I can think about is how you helped me practice it for the school talent show right before you left. [voice breaking] Was that goodbye?

[warmly] You were so nervous that night, kept forgetting the second verse. [chuckles] I told you to just feel the music, let Elvis guide you through it, and you, um, you lit up that stage like you were born to it.
[softly] You remember that?

[hesitantly] I've actually, uh, seen you perform three times this year. [pause] Different venues, always from the back, always leaving before the lights come up, but yeah, I've been watching you become everything you dreamed about.
[confused] Wait, you've been following my career? Why wouldn't you just, I don't know, say something, reach out, send a damn text message like a normal person who wants to reconnect?

[defensively] Because what do you say after twenty years? 'Hey, sorry I missed your graduation, your wedding, your divorce, your mother's death, but great Elvis costume'? [sighs] Some things are too broken to fix with words.
[quietly] Maybe. But you're here now, and the heating's broken, which seems, um, weirdly appropriate given how cold things have been between us all these years. [nervous laugh]

[gently] The heating system's actually an easy fix, just a faulty thermocouple that needs replacing. [pause] Takes about thirty minutes if you know what you're doing, which, well, after twenty years in the trade, I do.

[carefully] Thirty minutes, huh? That's, uh, that's about how long I have before I need to get into costume. Maybe you could, I don't know, tell me about those other shows you saw while you work? [trailing off]

[warmly] The one in Sacramento, you changed the arrangement on 'Suspicious Minds' and it was brilliant. [chuckles softly] Made it your own while still honoring what Elvis would have wanted, that takes real artistry.
[emotional] I can't do this, Dad. I can't just chat about my performances like you're some fan who hasn't destroyed me. [pause] But I also can't let you leave again without trying to understand why.

After the show tonight, there's a twenty-four hour diner two blocks north where I usually grab coffee when I work late venues. [very quietly] I'll be there until sunrise if you want to, um, if you want to talk about the why.

scenario: A tribute artist performing as Elvis discovers the gas fitter working on her venue's heating system is her estranged father who abandoned the family twenty years ago.
